newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Commission says clears legal bars to rail freight freeways.
newsitem.headline: Commission says clears legal bars to rail freight freeways.

text.p: The European Commission said on Thursday it had cleared the legal bars to the creation of trans-European rail freight freeways intended to cut goods traffic congestion on European roads.

Commission championing of so-called rail freight freeways is intended to raise the 16 kilometre/hour (10 mph) average speed of current rail freight journeys by creating seamless cross-border systems in place of existing national patchworks.
It has sketched out several possible routes linking German and Dutch ports to Italy via Austria and Switzerland.

Anti-trust issues have included questions about market access conditions to planned freeways and terminals, operator licensing rules and the rights of operators to compete for connecting business in other EU countries.

"The Commission has today clarified the application of competition law and other (European) Union rules thereby serving notice that it has completed the task for which it is responsible," it said in statement IP/97/460.

"There can be no real solution to the problems of congestion until we provide a safe, competitive, speedy alternative to the increasing dependence on road transport," Transport Commissioner Neil Kinnock added.
Commission figures for the freight market point to a 150 percent growth in road freight between 1970 and 1995 at the same time as market share for rail-borne goods has halved.
The first freeways could be in place by the year end, the statement said.
